Boy, I'm really conflicted. I am a System Administrator who deals with on-premise and cloud systems for my employer. I understand encryption and security and I'm all for privacy. One of the reasons I seldom post anything and I'm often heard saying---sarcastically--"It's comforting to know they're listening all the time." I'm reminded of the time I had my smartphone charging on my nightstand and my wife was snoring badly due to a cold she was dealing with. The next couple of days, Facebook was advertising snoring remedies for the first time ever. Creepy right?

My confliction is this. I have to assume that there have been a number of foiled attacks on targets in our country due to these measures. I ask myself, "Am I alive right now because an attack was thwarted?" The big question is how far is too far? What happens if we manage to make everything private again and the bad guys are able to take advantage. Maybe the bad guys have already found other means to privately communicate and my concerns are in vein. Makes for an interesting discussion.

BTW, side note. If you lock your phone with a swipe pattern or biometric, the fifth amendment will not protect you from self-incrimination because "something you do" (swipe pattern) or "something your are" (fingerprint) are not protected. The fifth amendment will protect you from "something you know" like a pin or password. Just saying.

As someone who studies US natsec law, I gotta say, with respect, SmarterEveryDay drops the ball here. At least when talking about how the Government does things.
The PA increased privacy & civil liberties protections, while streamlining already-existing authorities. When it expanded, it also increased P&CLs.
For example, prior to 9/11, the USG had no authority to issue Grand Jury Subpoenas for CT investigations—GJSs also didn't have Judicial oversight. When the PA came into law, this changed: Now GJSs allowed for CT, but those are now also under Court oversight. The first time the USG used its expanded authority was in 2003. Almost two years.

Another issue in the video: USP/aliens in the US, and their data are considered as protected by the 4th. This has never not been the case—extending to USPs outside the US.

Not only is there robust judicial oversight, but there is also Congressional: SSCI, HPSCI, HJC/SJC, etc. Who examine the Court record, and examine other executive branch oversight reports. This includes members of Congress, and their staff to visit HQ of the FBI, NSA, as well as field offices and collection sites, etc.
For Destin, I recommend the following academic materials:
On the Bulk collection of Tangible Things, David S. Kris. Indeed, I'd actually just recommend his treatise, National Security Investigations & Prosecutions 3rd edition, with Douge Wilson.
Prof. Peter Swire's testimony in the Irish High Court case, November 2, 2016. Specifically, Chapter 5 on oversight. You'll find on Alston. com

That privacy engine sounds like a good idea. And I know, living in Germany, that here with our privacy laws based on the European GDPR, many instances, in Germany for example the BSI, which is the Agency for safety in Information technology, recommends end to end encryption. A solution making this easy would sure help, as of today, you have to find individual solutions for everything.
But I see other problems as well. As we may have rather strict regulations in form of the GDPR, others have not (which voided two agreements on data exchange between the US and the EU, the Patriot Act based rights of the US government and thus the companies obligations did just not go together with our GDPR. For example if any of those companies stores my data on a server here in Europe, being a US company they have to give government agencies access and on order not to tell. In Europe such an access seems to have quite higher hurdles, and if it happened you have a right to know.
Another, even larger obstacle in my opinion is convenience. For most people it is convenient as it is. And most people are not even aware of an issue. So it takes a lot of informing, education and convincing people. As all devices of E2E encryption would be meaningless if you still have to communicate with other people unencrypted who don´t want to use it for whatever reason.
And if traveling, for some countries you have to be aware that using such technology would make you eligible for jail time. (Which should make anyone think twice if they really want or have to travel to such countries.)
Our GDPR is a curse and a blessing at the same time. It is a blessing to have such an instrument at all. But having to handle it and all the detail most people are not even aware of can be a nightmare, as it is awfully complex and complicated. And I am sure it is by no means perfect.
To give some examples of the complexity, taking pictures in the public can be a problem, if you depict a single person or a small group as main part of the picture, even if the picture was made for example in a public place. From videos on YouTube I know in the US (and to some extent to be honest also in Europe) cameras at your front door, especially those smart ones like ring or nest cams are quite popular. And I absolutely see that security cameras in certain situations are a good thing. Here you have to put a warning sign on the border of your property that there is camera surveylance in place. No matter if is recorded or if you just use it to see on your phone who is at the door. If the camera then maybe shows some part of the public walkway or street, that is a no go.
Or for example rather "innocently" sharing data about another person can be an issue (like writing about certain things about a certain person on social media), especially when it comes certain fields of data regarding health/medical stuff, sexual orientation, religion,... For example I may tell someone calling our company who wants to talk to a certain colleague that the person is on sick leave. But if I would tell for example, no he is not in today, he caught a flu, that would already be to much, as "harmless" as this information may seem. (They simply did not want to make an extensive and still incomplete list of what might be ok, like a flu, or cold or these days corona, or possibly other things you maybe do not want everyone to know about.)
If something like this happens on a social media platform, on request the platform by the way then also has to make sure it gets fixed, which may be an interesting aspect when some are "annoyed" about platforms deleting for example comments and they see the US first amendment endangered. (While automated algorithms and the companies themself "policing" the content to some degree is another issue in itself, with recent laws having providers to enforce certain rules with the least amount of work for official agencies, meaning for the social media companies, on their own, not exactly helping the matter)

Not to diminish your thesis or the work your team is doing, but I found my reaction to your video very interesting. While I'm sure many factors contribute to how one emotionally responds to novel information, my immediate reaction was to justify or defend the current data architecture. I would characterize myself as being somewhat informed about data privacy (for a layperson) and definitely in favor of stronger individual rights to protect their digital ecosystem from unwarranted and unwanted surveillance and misuse. That said, I was a bit stunned with the rationalizations I immediately came up with to defend the status quo and it really hit home how we are conditioned to view our lack of data privacy, among many topics, as a necessary evil of our modern society. In many ways, this is very much in the same realm of intrusion as secret police demanding your papers or congressional hearings asking if you or anyone you know is a communist. In those examples, we in the US have been conditioned (today) to view such acts as antithetical to democracy and freedom. With the issue of data privacy, we have been conditioned to accept the current system as the least bad alternative, whether it is to protect against terrorism, fight crime, or minimize the inconvenience of ecommerce and information transfer. I suspect that our conditioned response, or at least mine, is far from organic in its origins. Governments have always spied on their own people - see the aforementioned "papers please" example -  but today's version comes bundled with gigabit speed, unlimited data, and web browsing. Thanks for the interesting and important topic, I will now go black out my windows and put my tinfoil hat back firmly into place. - Cheers

I always wondered why security-oriented email providers didn't send "canari" emails to their users. An email sent, let' s say on a weekly basis saying something to the effect of "Hey, this is your weekly canary email, by which we certify to you that we have not been asked to provide data from your account by any government entity". And when you receive a subpoena you don' t send that canari that week. It' s fairly common practice in the security-sensitive software industry to publish canaris on a website at a regular interval to say that yo have not been been requested to compromise your software.

Dustin, The data center you highlighted in this video is on the property of the former Widows Creek Power Plant, now decommissioned and demolished. Widows Creek was owned and operated by the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). The data center sits on a small portion of the land that was the Widows Creek Power Plant property. TVA still owns the property. TVA is a public electrical utility that is actually a branch of the federal government and has major offices at the mailing address you highlighted in the video, hence the USA being listed as the owner of the site.
One of the things that made this property desirable for the data center is the electrical transmission line infrastructure that existed to transmit power out from the power plant. That infrastructure has now been repurposed to bring the large amounts of power into the site for the data center.

Use a "hard delete" utility to delete files - one that will overwrite the deleted info with binary zeroes. There is unfortunately no perfect solution. While having an end to end encryption service as you suggest solves a huge host of issues, it also introduces new ones. Chiefly, that now criminals and terrorist organisations have ways to use these networks to conduct themselves without any concern of being caught or interferred with. The sad truth is, criminals will always find away to abuse the system, whether it's through taking advantage of one full of leaks to sell and ransom your data, or by taking advantage of a super secure one to organise themselves without fear.

In my opinion, these systems need some level of oversight to stop these sorts of people and sacrificing small freedoms to achieve this is a necessary evil. I would rather risk my insignificant data being leaked than potentially enable the next terrorist attack by taking away the ability for law enforcement to monitor the people who need to be watched. Think about how a terrorist network could use a system with no oversight to distribute doctrine, bomb making manuals, and push recruitment with no fear of ever being caught. That is the other side of the double edged sword here.

Sending encrypted data to a corporations will not solve privacy because there won't be any services left. The data is the product for the vast majority of the internet. Being able to sell and trade that data is what keeps services free. You can have total privacy, but you will have to pay to use services if you ultimately intend to fully encrypt your data.

A better way to approach privacy is to forget about fully encrypting data. Instead, you should lobby for regulations that strictly only allow for non-personalized trading and selling of data.

Services will not survive by offering their service for free if all the data they get is a grabbled mess from their viewpoint. They need some portion of that data so that they can make money to cover their operating costs. Otherwise users pay out of pocket (or worse even more ad clutter and forced viewing).

F*** privacy. Why? Because each time our data is aggregated, anonymised, minimised or encrypted - we're decoupling our identity from it. This means we, as individuals, have limited legal recourse when use of that data ends up infringing our human rights. Quick example - you probably thought I was swearing when I typed f*** - and perhaps even thought twice about reading this because of that. That decision, in and of itself, is equivalent to discrimination, because you were relying on an incorrect assumption that was made as a result of the data being partially 'encrypted', when in-fact I had said "fair privacy". Hey Destin, thx for all your efforts on different topics. Love them! There is a fundamental aspect missing to the equation here. If we keep the metaphor of the cars engine: an engine still needs fuel. Changing the engine seems futile as long as we haven’t figured out tomorrow’s fuel. Yes we expect GAFAM to figure that out and the less they will get access to data, the more they will be forced or willing to find their future fuel. But user’s data is like gas, as long as there is some available, they won’t do anything about it. On the other hand, disruption could happen if we turn the problem around: figure out what tomorrow’s digital fuel will be. Figuring out a sustainable solution (definitely a complex problem) would by design reduce the interest in user’s data or even make it irrelevant.

Destin, I really enjoy your videos and this one is one of the best you put out.  I work in retail and every day I am totally amazed at how much people will readily pay for convenience.  Quite often people will pull out coupons, or ask for senior citizen, or military discounts and then not blink an eye when I tell them they will pay 4% more for using a credit card.  They could easily go to the grocery store next door and use their debit card to get cash and avoid the credit card charge, but they won't do it.  People will haggle over the price of something just to get another $5 off and then pay $20 extra in credit card charges.  So, the lesson here is that if your product or service can make things more convenient - you will succeed. If it takes a little - no matter how minute - more effort, people won't do it.  Please keep this in mind as you proceed, I wish you the best as this is a very important venture and I thank you for heading it up.

There is something funny about the privacy discussion: It has two perspectives to look at them and they are both bad. However whenever people talk about privacy they only talk about one of the sides and then claim the second side is the reason they can live with them.
The two sides are
1. The one mentioned here: Is your data safe and are others allowed to do stuff with it. - The response is well the data - price is as I get free products for it.
2. The one discussed by from a technical and political stand point: How do we services that apps, that actually serve you again, instead of just being made to collect your data. - The response is people are the product, but at least we can ask them to keep our data safe.

Since the video is just about point 1 I would like Destin to talk about part 2 as well, because it's really overlooked by the masses: Websites like Facebook, YouTube, etc. that in theory have nice content, but are designed to waste your time. More of your time means more knowledge about you and more ads they can show you. So you might not find what you are searchting for but something close enough and then another and another. When you search on YouTube only the first results are your actual search the rest is things you might like (even though it was search). Studies have shown that even after following 10 suggested posts the content becomes more and more radical, because a simplistic kind of view is more attractive than a controversial. Studies claims that our current extremist political view are fostered by websites that simply wanted to bind you attention, but for that fed you more and more radical "information". And now we at war inside our own country and even the president is not any more accepted by everybody but despised by half. Even if you don't go as far as this conclusion it's worth recognizing that there is no free service that really tries to 100% serve you but simply wants you to stay with them. LIke a restaurant that wants you to stay for the next meal and the next meal, not returning to your work or family, but just staying and get fat.

Your right about the end to end keys, The issue is how to implement it, you can't trust the ISPs to hold the key it would defy the purpose, i suppose custom routers would work that had a RSA key that negotiated handshake at the connection level, but then we have to work around ISP locked routers (Some ISPs force you to use their router, which there are ways around to an extent) But it raises another issue, both ends would need the hardware/software. I'm not highly verse in AES, but i know it doesn't have public/private keys, so that kinda wipes that, and with my minimal understanding of AES, how do you confirm key authority, my thought after 30 seconds of thinking about it, is how to you provide key authority globally, for example SSL keys go through an authority chain, but we couldn't do that here because that's giving someone else the key, so we need some mechanism that will tell User B that User A's key is valid. I suppose we could run a public key agonists each connection, but then somehow the connection must transfer the public key across the connection, which must be negotiated P2P e.g without central authority.

And i have to play devils advocate here a little bit, if your software has our key, isn't that the same problem? couldn't you be subpoenaed to supply our key, etc?

Going back to the end to end hardware/software issue, both ends need this for it to work, i realize your solution is more of a vault than an connection encryption, but the real problem is out-of-band encryption, it's how is it possible to encrypted data that we want to share on a public platform, or backup to a public cloud? FB, Google, Apple would never adopt this tech for obvious reasons, and aside from all of us being like me and have a rack full of servers on-premises to store and hold backups, email servers, public websites etc, all of which have their own roadblocks put in place by ISPs that want to discourage just that, i'm struggling for a way around the larger issue, the way social media is setup for example, it's an opt-in machine, you either comply or you miss out on all of what has become a commodity.

P.S i'm from Mobile ;)

“External key management service” is something that is getting pushed more and more in european countries, and we will see more integration work from cloud service providers. Confidential computing technologies combined with reproducible open source builds to verify the exact software you’re releasing your keys to is a game changer for what’s possible in cloud computing and privacy management. It’ll be on the consumers to demand transparent measurements of software that consumes an externally managed key that your tech is making easier to use. I push very hard for transparency as an engineer but the execs have to see the money to counterbalance the risk of exposing business logic in open source. You’ll get reproducible nonsense that only works when it pulls data from a service you down have access to. Vetting the code that handles decrypted user data will take huge organizations to keep up with constant updates. I hope upon hope that confidential computing gets more widely understood and consumers are rightfully wary of opaque modules whose only source of trust is a corporation’s signature

IMO, what is most important is not always privacy, but control over how your data gets shared. For example, some data might be more important to you to keep secret (you want to have full control over who to share it with, e.g. medical data, lifestyle data, the location of something valuable), whereas other data might be more important to be recoverable (you want to be able to restore it even if you lose your device, e.g. old projects, projects you're working on) - note that these might not be preferences or categorizations everyone agrees about, which is why **it is essential for the user to be in control**.

Destin, while I agree with privacy being an important topic, how would your new platform address the issue of criminal use of the Internet?  Terrorism is the one that we all hear about most often, but there are other issues as well, such as distribution of child pornography, tracking an armed robbery gang or ransomware threat actors?  Does your privacy platform address that?  You made one incorrect statement that I wanted to point out as well.  The statement that a user can have his online accounts subpoened and would never know is not accurate.  If there is an on-going investigation then it's important that those Internet companies can't be allowed to notify their clients; however, once the suspect's are arrested, or the investigation is over and they're not charged, that information can be released.  I'm sure you understand why it's important not to let the possible criminal know that they're being investigated.  Additionally, a subpoena only gets you basic subscriber information.  A search warrant is what gets investigating agencies account contents.  I would like you to research the process that police and federal law enforcement agencies have to go through before they get a warrant.  It's not nearly as easy as one would think.  My long diatribe aside, I've always liked your channel and I agree that there needs to be checks and balances in the system.  And there are.  They need to be updated as new technologies come into play, but the safety of citizens of our great country also need to be protected from those individuals and countries that maybe don't like us so much, or want to do evil.  Keep up the good work, just keep in mind, and report, on both sides of the issue.

Complex issue - here are my thoughts:

When the marching machine of the human race hit the industrial revolution, entities that had the resources started laying arteries of highway and railroad. The only ones that didn't were the ones that didn't have the resources, and they got left behind.

If you watched a time-lapse of the world from space you would see the growth and interconnection of the humans behave on a macro scale just as we see other species in nature behave. It's easy to forget that a skyscraper, a piece of litter on the road, is a part of nature's process and not separated by the limiting description of "man made".

This nature process drives our fate, and it cannot be stopped. As technology advanced we shifted towards a world of technocracies that run in layer with traditional governments.

We now live in the information age, and the power of that layer is made full by the new resolution of data available to it.

Nations are now not building railroads and highways, but 5g towers and higher resolution cameras, so that the flow of information is greater.

Drawing the line is complex because, say if another nation has their line in favor of power, do we cut off our own legs to protect our people's freedom? Maybe the guys behind closed doors have to be the bad guys, for our continued survival. That is a tough pill to swallow.

Fact correction at 9:10 "No outside accountability." Yes there is, lots. SIGINT agencies are regularly externally auditted. Additionally, personal information is only queryable either for National Security, Ecomonic Wellbeing (e.g. massive money laundering), or Prevention of Serious Crime. The necesiity for secrecy when auditting, challenging, and legally requesting such data should be fairly obvious if you give it a little thought. I do think it's high-time for such agencies to be more transparent with the general public though, since silence on these issues is only causing more and more conspiracy theories, even (it now seems) from well-respected broadcasts like this one. That your mobile phone records absolutely everything about your pattern of life, browsing habits, and so much more, on the other hand - that's something which I think we really need to deal with. Governments are driven by purpose - and in these cases, protecting their civilians. Tech companies, on the other hand, are driven by profit, and that's waaaay more dangerous.

This video uses some emotionally loaded phrases in order to attempt to convey the need for protection of personal privacy but it fails to convince me that 
a) my personal privacy is important enough to safeguard, 
b) that I have (or should have) a right to personal privacy, or 
c) that there is a valid motive for using my personal information against me.

Often, personal information is used in aggregate (together with everyone else's information) so there is really no concern about this. Other times, personal information is used by algorithms to better serve me (ie: show me ads/content that are more relevant and likely to appeal to me). This services both me and the companies paying for the ads so I don't have a problem with this. Either way, in these cases, there isn't a single person looking at the information of another single person so we need to stop talking about it as if there is.

Still, the video is correct in that: My individual, personal data COULD be accessed by another individual... and the idea of this is uncomfortable to a lot of people... but we must also keep in mind that the likelihood that it would ever be accessed like this is extremely small.

"Wait!", you say. "What about identity theft!" Remember, the data is only accessible by the tech company and the authorities. These large tech companies take this sort of thing very seriously because they know that their existence relies upon public confidence that this won't happen. That is not to say that it doesn't happen (because it does) but again, let's properly evaluate the risk and make informed choices.

I'm sorry but we went through the same things when personal computers started connecting to the internet. The only truly 'unhackable' computer is one that is not connected... but then, it's also not much use, is it? The answer is to find a proper balance and decide who you can trust... and this is the elephant in the room. Who can we trust?

There is a growing problem in our society and it has to do with the discounting and distrust of some of our most sacred institutions. When we no longer feel that we can trust the very institutions that we built to serve us, we have a bigger problem than someone knowing where we slept last night.

Firstly, the so-called "right to privacy" is a myth. The 4th ammendment only considers how information is obtained by authorities. I'd agree that "effects" should include digitized information, the key parameter for searching and seizing being "unreasonable." That said, secondly, we leave means of identification and evidence about ourselves wherever we go. Stepping out the front door reveals to anyone walking by that I'm 5'-8" and have brown eyes. If I trip and fall giving myself a bloody nose and leaving droplets on the sidewalk, I've left traces of my blood type and DNA for anyone who has an interest in it and the capability to analyze it.

Anyone can be actively conscious about what markers they leave behind, but we evolved in tribes and societies that enabled the great innovations we enjoy and profited on because we've shared everything with each other in the forms of skills, talents, and resources. Where's the line of propriety? It's about 200,000 years ago when we, essentially, became who we are today.

This is straight up fearmongering. You're starting to sound like people in facebook comments who act like we're living in in an Orwellian dystopia and they're the only ones that know it.

1) The frog analogy would have been useful about 15-20 years ago. The water has been boiling at full force for years and everyone noticed. It's just not that bad.

2) It's not like The Government (tm) is sitting there watching what everyone is doing. The risk is in a business getting hacked. It's in those business' best interest to invest in security. Which is always going to be a fight driven by the hackers.

3) Even if someone gets your data, so what? There's too much data for it ever to be about YOU. It will be about sending you spam (which there are plenty of blockers for). It will be about your profile as a separate, nameless entity. Your credit card company, for example, takes on this responsibility for you. That is the shift in society that makes it all work.

4) I'm all for extra protection for people that are still holding onto this illusion that privacy was ever a thing in the first place. Go nuts on this kickstarter all you want. It won't actually change anything. And it is just an illusion. You freely give out all of your precious information *all the time*. Your SSN, for example, is one of the most public things about you, yet people keep acting like it's a big secret you can't give out.

5) The whole system hinges on the data being out there. The data about how long you've looked at some pictures isn't going to hurt you in any way. It's going to mean you get more ads that you might actually be interested in. I don't need ads for tampons, for example. But I have found modern solutions to problems I didn't know had a solution, because of targeted advertising.

6) Honestly, truly, the whole idea reeks of ego. This idea that people are watching YOU and not that you've been reduced to a pile of digits.

Yes, we need to remain vigilant. Yes, we should pay attention to what we can pay attention to. But, no, I disagree in the original premise that there's a problem. At least a problem that regular people need to lose any sleep over. It's in the industry's best interest to handle data safety, or they will lose us, their product. It ends up being on them to fix.

If someone steals your CC info, because of all that data, it's very easy for the CC company to tell that those charges were not coming from you. When companies have a data breach and you need to change your password, big deal, you have to change your password. The company's reputation takes a massive hit, they hire a better security team and immunize themselves better.

This is already the best solution to a "problem" that is way, way bigger than us. This is a natural evolution of society and it cannot be stopped. And shouldn't. If anything, it gives more and more power to the people as we become more and more "the product" it becomes more and more in the best interest for companies to keep us happy.

I'm not saying don't be careful. Just, there's nothing to panic about. This is just a major shift in the environment that we'll all be better off adjusting to, not the other way around.

People happily type in and upload pictures and videos to places like Facebook all manner of things that they should have kept private. They willingly knowingly disclose all sorts of things. Then there are people who fill their homes with devices literally designed to listen (or even watch) every minute of every day. By design. People knowingly do this! And unfortunately, while not (yet) a majority, they're certainly a large enough minority to prevent privacy for the rest of us.

So fight the good fight! I'm with you. But it's a doomed cause. Because we've already past the point where too many people just don't care. And people like us? Today we're "conspiracy nuts". Or de facto criminals, guilty not by fact, but by a jury of our peers all the same. And every year that slide towards madness gets worse, not better. Sorry.

Over here in the UK we do have strong Data Protection Laws, so strong that when they came in some U.S. based operators had to change their processes or they were unable to accept UK and EU customers. Within our General Data Protection Regulations are 6 overarching principles which must be adhered to. And yes, it also covers metadata and biometrics. the Principles are: Purpose Limitation, Legal Requirement to Process, Accuracy, Integrity & Confidentiality, Data Minimisation and finally Storage Limitation. The Data Controller must have the individual’s express and unambiguous consent to do any of this otherwise the Data Controller can be liable for a very hefty fine.

I think your goal is laudable but ultimately unattainable. The problem is, I think, the public at large has grown accustomed to free services. Internet services cost a ton of money to operate (10's to 100's of millions of dollars per year) and getting the customer to pay for it is going to be difficult. Not impossible, but difficult. Consider all the free communications services that exist - that's your competition. Making the software behind it all open source doesn't make it free. Not really. The developers still want to be compensated and someone will have to pay for it all. In order for it to catch on (like the streaming TV services), you'll need to make its usage absolutely friction-free. The slightest inconvenience will drive the customer to say "This isn't worth $2/month" and will drop you for one of the free alternatives. I sincerely wish you luck. I feel the internet needs a major paradigm shift in how services make money, but the biggest hurdle is going to get consumers to shell out cash for it.

Honestly this app feels like killing a fly with an artillery canon. To use the 18th century analogy, there WERE entities that held data about you: your bank had your account number and transactions, if you were in a club they had you on the member roster, there were places you could look up someone's address without even knowing their name, and of course the town gossip (of which we have some record of through newspapers). A lot of these are GOOD things

The problem now is that there's certain data you want to share and certain data you don't. Again, using the 18th century analogy, you probably want to tell the bank you're taking the next clipper to Boston and will be needing to draw from your account at their branch there, but might not want your club to know more than "I'll be skipping the next meeting, will be busy" and the modern options are "tell the club everything" vs "tell the club nothing" or worse "share trip with everybody" vs "share trip with nobody"

The app's proposal seems to be to push more people to the latter option(s), which does not feel like an improvement

I used to work as a privacy expert in big tech. What a mess. A lot of my colleagues are still fighting for privacy, but what I saw made me too cynical to bother anymore.

First of all, there's the devs. Most are good people. Unfortunately, being a good person doesn't get you promoted. Increasing numbers in a spreadsheet does. Fortunately, for the most part, it's not profitable to collect data just for the sake of it. They do if and when they can use it to create value for the user, which is fair enough for me.

Governments are a very different story. They demand to know everything, while doing nothing valuable with it. And then they make "privacy laws", which sound good in theory, but have only even been enforced in corrupt ways. Essentially, they are excuses for ad-hoc taxes. No, the EU hasn't really done something that helps you yet.

And then there's the users. Users simply don't know what to ask for. People get obsessed with whether their name and precise location is shared. Companies can't use your precise location to hurt you (but governments can and do). And at the same time, people are ok with sharing their zip code and phone model, which is all a seller needs to raise prices on you. And even though I just informed you, you'll still care more about whether your phone knows where you had a coffee.

Neither our genes nor our institutions are capable of handling what is going on.

I really hope you debunk common internet privacy myths, such that VPNs help with your online privacy -- because they do the exact opposite; they hurt online privacy even more, by creating a false feeling that you're more private online. Your fellow Youtuber Tom Scott has already spoken about why he refuse to promote or be sponsored by VPN companies, and I'm sure he would love to collaborate on an internet privacy video for your series about why you should absolutely NOT rely on VPN for online privacy.

I think you could have done a more thorough job in stipulating the problem. "We need privacy" isn't nuanced enough.

Your solution is interesting. But you haven't addressed the obvious problem that we use a lot of free services. If those service providers lose our data, what then becomes of the free internet we use today?

Or start we a simpler question: a Kickstarter may get a project going, but it won't support a product long term. What's your business model?

A profit-making entity is going to do everything in its power to make a profit. Expecting these tech giants to be concerned about our privacy is wishful thinking. So, instead of questioning their intentions, let's question our dependency on their services. Do we really need a social media platform to stay in touch with people we care about? Do we really need an online shopping app to make us feel better about our lives? Do we really need to shop so much in the first place? When we can use cash for our transactions, why do we need to get dependent on digital wallets which only end up tracking our buying habits?

Do give it thought. If they have the power to track our information, we have the power to simply throw our phones in the dustbin and live a simple life. Allow this thought to seep in. WE DON’T NEED THEM, THEY NEED US.

13:55 If we are the product and the data we produce is paying for the services we consume, and if we do this "privacy thing", then we won't be giving the companies the data so they won't be willing to provide the same service, cause they won't be "paid". Which means that the same service will have to be paid directly by each user's money. Ain't that logical?

We are now not slaves of "Big Tech", we are willingly exchanging a relatively controled part of our data in exchange for useful services. That's not a secret, that's a viable business model. You can choose any time to stop using the services and consequently stop giving the data either permanently as a lifestyle or temporarily as a measure for any activity you don't want to share. There are valuable data that we don't want to share and we are paying to handle them either locally in the means of own server or data media or remotely by a company that we trust and that trust is secured by legal agreements with sanctions.

You can't have a privacy AND free service. You either have privacy and pay for the services (which would create a great inequality in access to such services) or you share a bit of yourself and have something in exchange.

A bit of feedback on your messaging: you spent a lot of time talking about unjustified access by law enforcement, but this is arguably an issue with the government, not the tech per se. When talking about how data leaks affect normal people you mention 1) spam 2) robocalls and 3) fake credit cards. Then one minute later you call lack of privacy an 'existential threat'. I think you should have done a lot more work justifying such a dramatic statement and focused more on how lax privacy hurts regular people

I guess my main question is: why is privacy important? While yes the government being able to buy all the data on a person for less then 300 usd is concerning, most of the time personal data is used for targeting ads and quality of life improvements, right? It is my opinion that privacy is an outdated construct and that society can advance a lot faster if we gave up the desire to horde information and to instead have complete free transfer of information. I mean at the end of the day who cares how long you looked at an image for, or what websites you visited, or any other mundane goings on of the average american?

Trouble is that its not a technology problem - its an economic problem. We (end users) want "free" services, and big tech companies are happy to "sell" those us those services by taking our data in trade rather than our money.

Now certainly everyone - users and companies alike - would love to see an end to the scourge of hacking that's constantly leaking everyone's data all over the place, that's not what you're proposing here. What you're proposing is preventing companies from selling our data. Which means they'll need another revenue stream in order to keep operating.


So we're back to having to pay for online services. Some would certainly argue, and not without merit, that that's how it should be anyway. But in reality its entirely impractical. We can give our data to thousands upon thousands of companies and still retain it ourselves to give to yet another company. We can't do the same with our money. Every $10 I give to one service is $10 I can't give to another service.

That gives us a strict upper bound on the number of services that can possibly exist in a data-protected world. And upper bound that would mostly be dominated by a handful of the largest and most well-known companies and stifling those who are unable to afford the necessary advertising to compete in any meaningful sense.

It would be a very different internet that's for sure. One that may be more private, but at the cost of being far less interesting. The site that we're all watching right now - YouTube - probably would not have existed if we were running a pay-for-play model. Even with the financial might of Google's purchase and AdSense, it took years for YouTube to start turning a profit. Of course advertising can exist without data collection, but its a lot less profitable to do it that way and would result in again far less interesting things on the internet.

And that's to say nothing of social media where the entire point of the platforms is to expose your information to the world. Those who are very knowledgeable about how the platforms utilize data can make some use of such platforms minimal risk by being very careful about what they post, but most people are stuck with a dichotomy of "use it and lose privacy or avoid it entirely and lose out on the "social" aspect of social media.

I don't have an answer for this. I don't know that there is an answer for this. Even if you have an app like Signal that is developed and distributed for free, somebody has to host the servers to connect you to your buddy - they might not be able to read your data due to the encryption, but it still has to go through their system in order to correctly route it to the recipient.

Signal itself runs off of donations. That's great and all but it doesn't really scale for the same reason direct-pay apps don't scale - there is only so much people can (or at least are willing) to donate. A few specific apps? Sure. But you can't run an entire internet that way.

Anyway, I'm not trying to claim your effort is useless by any means. Increasing privacy for those who want it is a good thing. But the idea of a completely private internet is not really plausible unless we can come up with something else that is both valuable enough to provide revenue for a business and infinitely copyable like data is.

Nice idea, but there are at least 2 problems coming to my mind that you will not be able to solve:

1st: People are using social media platforms (like Facebook, YouTube, etc.) to have other people see their data. So you can not encrypt it and you have to play the game that the platform provider set up for you.If you can only use the platform by e.g. also giving you actual location, you will do it even if it was a dumb idea (people know meanwhile that Facebook gathers data it should not be gathering but they still use Facebook). This will not change. So what is the benefit of securing your data on one end if you give it away for free on the other end?

2nd: Even if you encrypt all your data via an app, the app itself has to run on a operating system. This system can still spy on you before your app encrypts the data. Also, the app will not encrypt data that the operating system is collecting and sending out by itself. The app will also not be able to keep other parties (like government, device provider, etc.) peeking into the data that is stored on your device. To do so, you would have to use/build an open source operating system which you would have to maintain yourself. On one hand, close to all of the people are unable to maintain such an operating system (knowledge wise or time wise), on the other hand, companies like Microsoft and Apple will never (!!!) make their operating systems open source.

I do understand the worries that make SmarterEveryDay want to build their own privacy app, but working in this field myself (I am an IT consultant and project manager), I doubt that the app will make your privacy any better than it is today (there are already a lot of solution out there the encrypt you data and defend your privacy - and still your data is open to whoever is paying enough money or has enough power (e.g. government)). I will have a look at the kickstarter - just for fun - but my expectations are that the app will not be capable of really securing your privacy or will never be finished or will go the same way that other apps already go (and therefor not making your situation any better).

Respectfully, some of your oversimplifications, to aid in layperson understanding, may go a little to far. For example, your assertion that cyber crime is made possible because our data is "sitting unprotected," is in most cases factually inaccurate. The institutions that collect and store our data have financial motivations to keep our data as secure as they believe possible (notice I didn't say "keep secret" - obviously they have financial motivations to sell that data to advertisers). Keep in mind cyber vulnerabilities may not be known or disclosed to vendors, let alone the public, meaning malicious cyber actors who identify those vulnerabilities can act without industry knowing there's a security vulnerability. Cyber Defense is a losing game: its not a matter of "if" there will be a breach, but "when." All that aside, just about everything you said was right on point and I'm very excited to see how you can break down this INCREDIBLY complicated issue in the coming episodes as well as how the technology you're developing will change up the cyber landscape!

I appreciate the goal and the concern, but I don't think complete internet privacy is possible anymore even with end to end encryption (which is the best we got) as there are just too many work arounds.
a) other people can share it once they get it.
b) you presumably want the data manipulated in some way to return useful results. If it is not done locally(some processes will be to intense for consumer hardware) the service provider can read it then. If it is done locally and closed source code then they can store and hiddenly send it later when you connect for other reasons (i.e. updates or website connection). If done open source then you could maintain your privacy, but that might be to risky to businesses with competitors.
c) in extreme cases hardware monitoring hacks (ie. your program monitors the power fluxuations while the key is being generated to reverse engineer it, if you were clever you could even get your open source code to generate a clear pattern just before and after the key generation giving you flags to work with)

Hopefully you can prove me wrong though.

Don’t tell me that my data is for sale; nobody denies that. Instead tell me why I should care. What bad things will happen to me as a result? “Existential threats” isn’t really meaningful.

Your argument of a time-traveler from the past isn't really valid as the same person would probably be disgusted and terrified of things like LGBT culture, social care, current technology in general... the slow cooking of the frog in reality is just change and we must acknowledge the real risks of technology, and the realities of the age of internet.

Today I can download a book on how to make explosives instantly, order online or go to a store, and have a simple homemade bomb the next day. Same principle (with variations in time and difficulty ofc.) applies to homemade viruses, nuclear reactors, firearms, poisons etc..

With the rise of internet individuals gain increasingly bigger damage potential so it's logical we have to keep tabs on people, even with the unwanted side-risks for the same reason laws exist; they limit our freedoms for the betterment of our society, for security and peace.

It's not something we should fight against. We should push it in the right direction to streamline the process and minimize the risks and side-effects involved (corruption, data-leaks, unethical uses, authoritarianism etc.). The real problem is that currently our data is owned by corporations.
But there simply are higher risks at stake if we go 'back to privacy'.

In regards to the land being owned by the government, it is a way for large companies to avoid paying taxes for several years. Long story short, the company promises to hire a certain amount of local people at certain average wages, promises to lease the land for a certain number of years, etc, etc and in exchange don't have to pay tax for a while (usually a "just" a few years) on any profits generated from that physical location. Almost every large corporation you can think of takes advantage of these programs because it (almost always) ends up being a win win situation for both the company and the local area. So it's pretty darn common.

Destin, equally as important as data privacy is financial privacy. The only answer to this is Crypto. Not all crypto networks are private... some are quasi-anonymous, or can be made to be anonymous by an educated end user, some aren't remotely private, and some are truly private like Monero.

Whatever financial system we use in the future, it must be private, or the government and other bad actors can know everything you've ever purchased and when and where, and every penny you've received, and every donation you've made. That is especially dangerous in today's political climate, and is how America can implement a Chinese social credit score type system in a way no one sees coming, based not just on politics but new ESG scores and regulations, which are bogus.

10:15 I'd be wary of conflating government, commercial, and criminal access to your data. There are some similarities between the three, but also significant differences: first, in how much access we reasonably might want them to have (presumably none for criminals, but there are some good reasons one might want to allow some commercial or government use); second, in how said access is determined (government is a matter of law, commercial a matter of terms & conditions, and criminal a matter of cybersecurity).

To this point in the video, you'd been talking about government access (and to a lesser degree commercial access), but then all of the sudden pivot to criminal when it comes to "how will this effect your life." Which is to say, you go to the "big government" when you think primarily about what your program will prevent, but "big crime" (or "big spammy-but-technically-legal business") when you want to convince people that privacy is important.

So while I support the idea of end-to-end encryption and better web infrastructure for such privacy obligations, you have failed to convince me that this is in any way the most important part of the problem when it comes to the stuff I care about (namely criminal access - gaining passwords, opening credit cards, etc.). [And when I say "stuff I care about" I mean both in terms of what I actually care about and in terms of what your argument says I should care about.]

Great idea, I see a couple of major hurdles to overcome:
One problem with end-to-end encryption and Signal is the risk of losing your key. I was using Signal, changed phones, forgot to copy my key and lost everything. While that is obviously my mistake, if you want this to work for everyone, especially the less tech literate, you need to somehow prevent user error.
I notice your app is presented as a subscription, people have a strong view that the internet is free and if you charge a regular subscription, people will instead use the free, less secure options. I don't think a subscription model can work in the long term if your goal is to change things on a large scale.

I'm far less concerned about the tech companies giving data to the government than anything else, and if I may, I'd like to share why. If the government does something messed up with my data, if it comes to light (its federal government composed of well over a million Americans. It'll get out. After working for my state, I'm certain of this.) Then there will be public outcry, impactful protest, widespread distrust, unpredictable voting: things harmful to a nation, its government, and also the politicians who were remotely involved (also potentially threatening them and their families). Nobody in government benefits from it. On the opposite side, the government can do greatly valuable things with this data that could potentially avoid another 9/11 or other attack. Obviously this is a great thing.

When a company does something corrupt with data, it's so common it gets overshadowed and forgotten quickly, like Cambridge Analytica. If this was the gov. it would not have gone like this. Little to no good can come from private companies giving away data to each other. Unlike the government, this data will not be used remotely for security or purposes that benefits or protects American citizens, and its also likely to fall into the wrong hands in these transactions.

In summary, I'm fine with this argument, but I find the mention of government as the problem to be very weak, and the lack of mention of private companies' data sales to other companies without user permission to be disappointing.

So I work as a developer in the advertising and ad bidding space. In other words, part of the ad infrastructure that makes the internet work. So the targeted ads that you see, often relies on data that does NOT get passed through the big tech companies like Facebook and Google. The question that I have, is how to think of a secure "user data environment", as it pertains to targeted ads. After all, simply buying something off of a website gives that company enough information to target you for future ads. Thus why your ads might change even after simply visiting a particular site.

And after all, targeted advertising still does SEEM to be preferred to untargeted, because otherwise the value of advertising drops way down, and everybody gets the same trashy ads. Spam email kind of works on that principle. So does your movement here address this? How does advertising even work in the world you are envisioning?

You store half of the bits of information in store1. Half in store2 and the correction bit in store3.
Nobody will know which bits are stored where.
The storagealgoritme has a form of encryption.
To decrypt you will need at least 2 storage locations together with a decryption key.
The networks traffic would always be split in at least 3 streams.

What I take issue with in this particular video is that you make it very much seem like the privacy concerns are just on governments having basically unauthorized access to your data.
The reality of it is very different though: If companies like Google would not try to one up each other to see who's algorithm can best calculate your personality down to a tee then there would be no data for the government to search through. As you rightly point out, pretty much everything gets logged. From the amount of keystrokes I do per second typing this comment, the content of said comment I am currently typing which is scanned even before I post it, the amount of time I spent watching your video, the browser and system information of the device I watch it on making me uniquely identifiable, how focused I was during it as seen by mouse movements and engagement with the video, millions of factors so incredibly minute in detail your jaw will drop once you first realize the true extend of this.
To me you make it sound like this isn't the actual true underlying issue. You're making it sound like government surveillance is the problem. And don't get me wrong, it absolutely is part of it, but government surveillance is an entirely different story from private companies calculating your every move.

I mean, let's not also pretend that any company that's being forced to subpoena data is entirely innocent either, after all, it's kind of their fault that they have such data in the first place, and I wouldn't be surprised if selling that data specifically to governments is built into the profit margins of those programs. More than just "personalized advertising" we have to understand that this data, this digital copy of you, tracking where you are at all times, conceptually, at some point in the future, even predicting your behavior, it's not just valuable because it can show you some underwear ad you'll skip over. It's valuable because it can control you. If you can predict someone's behavior, you control that person. I wouldn't be surprised if many of the common complaints about misinformation circulating on these services are entirely intentional on the part of the algorithms simply doing their job.

Now, this isn't to say that being able to predict someone's behavior, that having this control over people, is even necessarily a bad thing. Conceivably, you might even use such a system to, say, educate massive amounts of people on some issue they knew little about (wow, what a shocker), to be able to change their minds more effectively. It's not even like you can say they didn't really have any control over whether or not their minds were changed, you can't say their free will was violated, because it's questionable that if such a thing can exist, that they had any in the first place.

Even having ownership over an idea, even if you've produced it, is a strange and perhaps incredibly damaging extension of regular property rights, which are already somewhat questionable in the first place. I mean, perhaps data could be seen more as labor, or less of an idea, and more just your day to day actions, it's dubious to define it any one way. Knowing whether or not someone's gone to the store, knowing their schedule, it's not inherently immoral, it's just creepy because it facilitates worse actions and abuses. In my mind the problem here isn't that this data is being held, even, but that I have no control over what anyone decides to do with it. You've correctly identified the problem, they (Big tech corporations) have control over our (the user's) data. But the tendency to hyper-exaggerate individual agency and free will isn't necessarily ideal either, that's a step in the totally opposite direction. Everyone sharing their metadata not only shows us what your own personal schedule looks like, it has the possibility to revolutionize the field of sociology. Now, instead of having to do a study on whether or not people get discriminated against or oppressed, or whatever, whether or not someone has control over their own lives, what strange common factors might be at play, I can directly know the answers to all of these questions. That's the real power of this data.

Also 9:27 I feel like that comment about it happening more than most people realize is a bit misleading. Pretty much everyone in the USA, Canada, etc use google in some form or another. Of course it happens often, Gmail alone has around 1.5 billion active users alone, not counting any other service attached to google itself. Not saying your message is wrong because I agree laws need to change and privacy is important just... that comment hovers on the edge of being needlessly fear inducing (not "mongering" because I don't think your doing it on purpose).

Even more so in conjunction with the comment about how the land is owned by the government, it gave me big conspiracy theory video vibes (flat earthier, etc) not saying there isn't something there but with you just mentioning "well not sure what that means I just wanted you to KNOW" then leaving it at that... it kinda tries to induce fear. There might be something there that's sinister ... or there could be a dozen other things going on such as the transfer of the land hasn't gone through yet OR that fact that it might be a facility that houses government or government related info. People will naturally be compelled to think the worse.

Or the comment about how the government can request your personal info without any oversight, which isn't totally true. To get a subpoena the government/police/etc has to show a judge that the information they are requesting is pertinent to a ongoing investigation and the information would help the case. There is oversight there and this HAS been abused and might need MORE oversight. But needing more oversight doesn't mean there isn't ANY oversight.

The comment that they can do it without your knowledge isn't totally true either, In particular Reddit and Google will actually notify you if your info has been subpoenaed and will even inform you that you have X amount of days (usually 7) to file a motion to squash the subpoena before they will have to comply with it because they have to notify you by law because you have a right to try to squash the subpoena. Can agencies get a subpoena for info and Google/Reddit/ etc wont notify you? Yes... but that's mostly found in the extreme cases (terrorism and such).

Then you show us this app you have a vested interest in which you ask us to enter all our private info.... which you mentioned was one of the starts of this whole issue back when social media came out (entering our private info into a system). I love your channel and you have a great message but the way this video played out just comes off wrong.

Whats the point of entering all my private info into this app? I know you call it a "proof of concept" but the kickstarter make it seem like its more than that. I noticed a picture on the kickstarter says you can enter your passport. Why? There is not point to do that because no one would accept a phone picture as a official document. Now we are just entering our even MORE important info onto the internet because that's what this does, secure or not it still GOES on the internet for really no reason unless the info is just stored locally, in which case.... there's even less point to the app in my eyes.

Hi Dustin, love your channel and this new series! I was just having a conversation with my wife about digital privacy, and how things like SSN and Passports are going to be replaced by tokenized versions on a blockchain. I'm still new to learning about blockchain, but my basic understanding is that you could theoretically store an encrypted version of all your data on a blockchain, and then provide tokenized access to those who need some piece of your information, such as for an employment or apartment application. Ideally, the SSN, for example, would never be viewable by the employer or landlord, because their systems can't be 100% secure, but the tokenized version would be recognized by the credit check agency. A similar idea is when I share a password with another person through a password manager without them being able to see or save it.

Frog?!? EPIC, the EFF, and countless concerned citizens like me have been screaming this stuff at the top of our lungs since the Patriot Act was introduced. This was not a slow boil, it was an immediate abdication of duty by law makers, courts, and the citizenry. It would be great if enough people started caring now to change things, but I'm skeptical that anything will/can substantively change without a landmark SCOTUS precedent or an unlikely constitutional amendment.

Edited to add: I am grateful to Dustin for bringing this to the attention of his audience. Just frustrated about how we got here, and it has to be changed legally, because even the best encryption keys will be vulnerable, particularly when governments & others eventually start using quantum computing to laugh away our silly encryption keys to see encrypted data.

Well ... what does the app you promote do different than a bunch of other apps over the last decade, all of which failed at least partially to adress that problem?

Apparently, it will implement revocable access rights. Nice! But how? What keeps me from taking a screenshot of the photo someone sent me? If someone temporarily shares an audio file with me, why wouldn't I re-record that file from the audio device playing it? If the client is closed source, why would I trust it? If it is open source, why wouldn't I fork it and implement a function, that is automatically storing all temporarily decrypted data on my local device? Since it was said, the app won't need phone numbers to work, will I need some other sort of user account? Where does it live and who is securing that account? How will I find and contact other users? If I send an encrypted 500 MB video to a couple of friends, will it be stored on a server? Why would I trust that server? Will it be stored on their devices? How can I revoke access, if they aren't online? Is it stored on my phone only and I will have to stream it, when someone wants to see it? How does the app help against a big brother government, when every update coming though the android or apple stores could contain an altered version? Where is the white paper or the proof of concept elaborating all that stuff? And where is you team of experienced security researchers implementing it in a safe way? Neither the kickstarter page, nor the 4privacy website explain any much of that. So ... why would I back it?

In about 1970, my Grandpa told me about "free" newspapers.  He said every transaction has four things: a buyer, a seller, some "stock in trade" (either a product or service) and some money (or something that's traded).   He asked me, when I picked up the free paper, which one was I?  I can't be the buyer, because I didn't pay.  I'm not the seller because I was still broke.  And I'm not the money, because I'm not green.  So, I was the stock in trade.  The publisher sold my eyeballs to the advertisers, and got paid real money for them.

End-to-end-encryption is a step, but most apps that currently implement this still read and analyise your content (and usage behaviours, etc.) on-device and then store this meta-data on their servers. So encrypting the content in-transmission isn't enough to prevent them from gathering information on you, though the contents of your messages are secure from third-parties.

Encryption keys do not work unless BOTH parties protect the data. We use encryption in business, but that's during the transmission process. Once it's received on the other end, that is where the problem begins. If THAT end user does not protect that data, it is available to anyone/everyone, resulting in millions of new end users (aka the public).

While all of this sounds great, here's the problem that I see with this.

Take the "If you don't pay for the product, you are the product" idea. If we would see this suddenly popularized and turned into a law, everyone now needs to implement this feature. Companies now lose their user data completely. What happens then? Either the companies go bankrupt, because their business model is completely broken, or we now need to start paying for everything that has been for free. Would people start paying for YouTube, their Gmail, Facebook, Spotify, etc, etc... And how much?

I think the biggest problem now is the scale, everything has simply gotten too big. The analogy of cars and engine is fine, but I think the analogy where our user data is gas is better. You can't simply switch out the fuel, and keep using the same engine/car. Basically everything needs to be dismantled and built from scratch. It's like a machine with 10'000 moving parts all tightly packed together, and you must switch out one gear for a different one that's twice as big. Nice idea to think about, but unfortunately unrealistic to legitimately come to pass.

I just have one question. Even if all of this works, the tech industries we’re targeting like Facebook depend on owning our information to keep running. Our information is the product they sell as a company. So going back to your engine analogy, you’re not replacing the engine, you’re just taking it out. What will the internet run on if not our data? My guess is that they’ll have to start charging to provide those same services. Will people be willing to pay for a Facebook account? I don’t know. And perhaps the best argument would be that people should have the option to either sell their data or pay for an otherwise free service. That’s really what it’s going to come down to, and that applies to using the Internet in any capacity. Privacy will simply be another service one pays for, although it’s kind of sad that privacy is now a service and not a right, although in a capitalist society, there’s an argument to be made that everything is a service and nothing is a right. One of the bugs in the system I guess.

Anyway this is a fascinating topic and privacy does come at a cost assuming it’s even possible in today’s day and age. I’ve always assumed I’d be fine because A) there’s anonymity in numbers, making use of that much data is pretty challenging, that’s what AI and the study of big data is trying to figure out and B) I don’t really have anything to hide. Obviously terrorism will be easier the more privacy we have and it will be more difficult to solve crimes and to uncover abusive relationships with partners and children etc.. But losing our privacy also comes at a cost too. The psychological toll of always being watched and never having a private space will be devastating, the government will overreach, people will be taken advantage of, and as of right now, we aren’t using that data for anything useful. All we us it for is figuring out how to sell as many things to people as possible. Clearly there’s some issues with both sides. And privacy vs safety has always been a difficult discussion. We’ve always leaned towards protecting privacy, especially from tyrannical leadership, and yes, having ownership of other’s privacy is a very totalitarian thing because it works wonders on people’s psychology when you want them to fear you. So it’s all a really difficult topic.

Putting all of that aside. I think we need more options, so I’m glad Destin is doing this. It’s not really going to solve any of the other major issues plaguing social media and our interconnectedness and the fact that we have access to more free speech than ever before, but it’ll give us options and it gets us talking about things.

I think what we have now is comparable to the history of the Stasi in post war Germany.  The data in the cloud is a massive national security risk.  Politically this data can be used to compromise people at all levels of the government, finance and tech companies.  In post-war Germany people were turned against each other with information collected by the Stasi.  Virtually everyone in post war Germany on the Soviet side had a file.  To this day those files are sealed away as family members and friends were sometime unknowingly working against one another.  People were turned in to the Stasi for simple revenge or profit.  It was a dangerous society to live in because sharing seemingly benign information with the wrong person could be deadly.  Just imagine a foreign intelligence agency compromising someone with in each big company's data center.  The amount of blackmail they would have would be priceless to them.

You should do a segment on how encryption works. It's legitimately fascinating and would also help people understand why current standards aren't enough. I always figured "having a password" was basically the best you could do but I heard a great analogy for end to end encryption that really changed my perspective as a novice. Basically if you have a package to send you put a lock on it and you keep the ONLY key. The other guy receives it and adds another lock and they keep the ONLY key to that lock. They ship it back, you remove your lock, you ship it back again, they remove their lock and they're in. No mailing keys around no way for the mailman to sneak a peak. I thought that was an excellent way to simplify it for the luddites among us and I would love to see what you could add.

What data do we consider private, however? We used to have phone books that listed your home address and phone number, and it was no more difficult than calling a telco and asking for a phone book for some distant place for free. Why should email addresses, names, and phone numbers be private? I’m all for privacy, but we have to pick our battles, and some data isn’t worth protecting. I don’t care who knows what I buy on Amazon, or what my email address is. The key is to be smart what data you give out, because if you’re depending on regulations to force companies to keep our data private, you’re looking at the wrong solution.

Don't forget that any device you use to transmit your private data can be compromised.
I am not just talking about android phones running google apps, google phones, iPhones etc etc who are all tightly connected to said data collection companies.
I am talking about the actual hardware.

The problem is, these smartphones are already tied into a data collection hive. Just because you run an app to encrypt everything doesn't mean the backend of these devices aren't leaking your data in some capacity.
But more importantly, keep in mind where all the processing power comes from, what country is making all these phones hardware... You can't really be sure these countries haven't started a batch of modified hardware with a literal wiretap installed that occasionally transmits data directly to the manufacturer of the device. Or even starts doing it on request from said manufacturer by a hidden signal.

For absolute ensured privacy, you'd have to make the device you are using to encrypt something entirely yourself. Otherwise you are still putting all that trust into a company you don't even know exists.

Privacy / anonymity is great in theory but not necessarily in practice ... those with power will find it easier to hide their abuses as their communications will be harder (or perhaps impossible) to make transparent ... and they'll in turn demand that they retain the keys to the back doors. I don't think we need better privacy, we need better oversight ... oversight in the form of requiring warrants, oversight in the form of professional and ethical journalists, and oversight in what these tech companies are doing with our data, who is buying it, what they're using it for, etc.

Alas, the US seems to hate oversight, and so the rest of the world has to suffer.

One very common -- and unwarranted practice of discount and department stores really pisses me off.  When you pay for your purchase with a credit or debit card, they  permanently STORE your card information in their computer.  This is NOT needed and highly suspicious.   Your card information is only need for a few seconds -- long enough to process the transaction electronically (in those few seconds the card is verified and the money is instantly deposited into the stores bank account), after which they have no use for it.  The entire transaction is finished.  If they have you sign the receipt (or do it on a little screen), that document goes nowhere.  The store will keep it for about 30 days in case there's a problem (like you later deny making the purchase), then they simply throw it away.  You may have noticed that in little stores and restaurants they swipe your card in a little box on the counter and enter the charge manually, this transaction also happens instantly but those little boxes (most) don't store the card information (they have no memory and aren't connected to a computer -- they communicate with the merchant system directly via a network or phone connection).  Those merchants always get their money (instantly) and there is no problem.  Big stores with computerized point-of-sale (POS) systems are flagrantly violating and risking your privacy by storing your card data on their system.  I don't even know why they do it, other than they can.  They can't enter another charge without your permission, and if you come back for a refund they can simply swipe your card again.  Several years ago I made a small purchase at Target.  A week later I got a letter from Target Stores informing me that their system had been hacked and my credit card information was stolen.  I had to cancel my card, order a new one, update all my autopay accounts (Netflix, Hulu, AT&T, Paramount+, Showtime, and many more).  This theft could not have happened if those %&^$! hadn't stored my information to begin with.  I'm somewhat shocked that this has never been addressed -- and STOPPED!  Every major retailer -- including virtually ALL online businesses store credit card data despite the obvious risks and total lack of benefit.  We should all call our congressmen and demand legislation to prohibit storing credit card information after any one-time purchase.  Obviously subscription services need to keep your card data so they can charge your card every month, but even then if you cancel the subscription you credit card information should be completely destroyed and not saved ANYWHERE in their system -- not even the backups.  Millions of credit card numbers have been stolen from these retailers -- who have varying success at cyber security.  Again, they have no need to save credit card information, it's literally useless to them 10 seconds after the sale.  This is a gigantic serious problem that EVERYONE needs to care about.  If retailers had not been storing credit card information, the only way credit card numbers could be stolen is if banks got hacked -- which is pretty rare.  Everybody should be bitching about this because it's unfair, uncalled for and a grievous violation of our privacy.  Just sayin'
