"I have nothing to hide" is the dumbest, most naïve statement one could possibly say. Whenever and wherever people are involved, mistakes are inevitable. You might have nothing to hide, but your room mate might. If you share the same DSL service provider with your room mate, companies/the government can confuse your internet traffic with your room mate's internet traffic, especially if the traffic is not associated with a user account on some website. And suddenly, you are associated with the stuff your room mate puts on the internet without you knowing. In the worst case, you will be classified as a murder for stuff your room mate has done. The entire chain between your device and the service you are connecting to (including the service itself) has unbounded potential for human error, and you are the one who has to suffer the consequences. Tell me with a straight face that you trust everyone involved in the chain between you and Facebook to be infallible (despite numerous data leaks), and that you rather put inconspicuous, but potentially harmful information on the internet than to think twice about whether it is really that necessary to post an image of your new coffee mug on Facebook.

In 2020, Facebook made 98% of its earnings from Facebook Ads and Alphabet (Googles parent company) made 80% of it's earnings from AdSense.

The obvious idea of charging for services to recuperate the losses caused by pivoting to a privacy centric model doesn't seem very likely to take off. Most people I know, including myself, don't want to or can't afford to start paying for all of the services they use online. There needs to be some other money making ingredient thrown in the pot for this to work in my opinion.

After watching the deeper look video I really have one question, but before I ask I want to say some things. First, I agree with you, privacy is key and currently the internet thrives on user data (lining the pockets of many tech companies). Second, I currently work in cybersecurity (saying this to hopefully convey my understanding of the technology).

Given that user data is so valuable to tech companies do you see the tech companies "taking this lying down" so to speak. To reference the example in your kickstarter video, even if someone accesses my information temporarily, that data still exists in memory unencrypted. While I wouldn't be worried about another "user" doing this, what is keeping or preventing big tech companies from essentially running a memory scraper on their own systems and farming our data that way? It would be as simple as updating ToS, which you aptly pointed out no one reads. Given how valuable our data is I wouldn't put this outside the relm of reason for a big tech company to do.

What surprise me, as an European, is why people in the USA doesn't seem to care enough to request a constitutional change about this issue. The 4th amendment is just brutal. People are concerned about the Chinese spying you, but at the same time gives all the power to the government to access their data whenever they wanted. Even for us, Europeans with our strong privacy laws, cannot feel secure due to the expansion of the biggest northamerican corporations. I have my backups and personal files in a key encrypted European cloud service, sure, but at the same time I'm kind of forced to use a Google/Facebook/Apple product here and there doing unknowing things. You northamericans have to stop this, because we love your technology and culture, but this privacy violation is just too much. I cannot wait for the rest of the videos, great series, this is a topic I'm very into, and sure I'm gonna take a look at your Kickstarter project. A+👍

Problem with the encryption approach is that has side effects that people won’t accept:
+ Value added features like spam filtering and email history search don’t work if the provider can’t index your email
+ End-to-end encryption means the provider can’t help you recover your data if you forget your password or key and are locked out
+ You can’t access your data from any device (with signal for example you can’t move your history and contacts from Android to iPhone)

As a web developer by hobby and IT Sys Admin by day, I appreciate the idea behind this campaign, but in order to accomplish what you actually want, 90% of people would probably lose everything.

You want to store private encryption keys on user devices... that is absolutely crazy, the whole point of these services holding the private keys is they have built the redundant infrastructure required to reliably keep that key intact "forever". If you want keys stored without the service provider having access, that means storing the key on personal hardware, which is usually orders of magnitude less reliable than the mirrored raided and replicated systems the service providers have built.

If a drive crashes or a computer is accidently thrown away with the key, the user loses all of their data.

Sure, I can handle something like this because I do this for a living, but to expect the lay-person to have the hardware and systems in place to accomplish something like you're suggesting is naïve.

Privacy never existed in the first place. Whole families used to live in one common living room, with no dividers. Think about that. Before technology, everybody knew everybody else's business. It was just more local, meaning everybody in your town knew everything you did at any given moment, but in the next county nobody knew you existed.

The modern world has flipped that. Now the whole world knows your business, but you have walls and boundaries that give you an illusion that nobody near you knows your business. Guess what? They do, and always have.

That doesn't mean you shouldn't be concerned about your privacy, it just means you need to be aware of what it really means and worry about the things you can control and not the things you can't.

I know you're really smart, so let me make the case for why privacy HAS to go away. Not just a little, but 100%, completely gone. My turn to convince YOU, the opposite of your argument:
We are quickly approaching a level of technology where a single individual with modest means and a grudge could pose an existential threat to the entire species. We may be there now. Where a single individual could produce, in a small private lab, modified viruses. For the cost of a home, someone could purchase most of the equipment necessary to do this. They'd simply need the knowledge and every day new students are being educated in it. Imagine if someone produced several viruses. Viruses based on past deadly viruses. Probably wouldn't be too hard to find a few Spanish flu in some cemeteries in the Siberian permafrost. So there's a nice little starter virus to get you going. Maybe find some smallpox victims, since nobody's getting vaccinated against smallpox. Those of us in our 50s are among the last to be vaccinated against it. And then modify them. A little genetic engineering and you can make them even more deadly.
My point is, that this is a pretty feasible scenario and becomes increasingly so as time goes on. Put your viruses in some spritzers, and take a few international flights around the world, spraying planes and airports as you go and you suddenly have a pandemic in a matter of days.
What we need is technological telepathy. The ability for us to read each other's minds, obviously via technology, since we don't have the natural ability. It's the only way I can think of to really ensure that a single individual doesn't wipe out the species.
And don't tell me about colonizing Mars. or something. We can't even keep a 8 people alive in a desert for a year without cheating. You think taking away the atmosphere and dropping the temperature 100 degrees is going to improve the odds? We have one home planet and we have nowhere else to go. We need to come to terms with that and figure out how to not kill ourselves.

End to end encryption is great at preventing man-in-the-middle attacks, but it doesn't prevent a (for example) CPU manufacturer from implementing literal wire tapping at the silicon level and gathering information. Line snooping is already common place for things like caches, and considering the level of complexity of modern processors, crazier things have been done.

Apple has their own ARM core now, if they really wanted to they could implement something like this to get around software encryption. After all, software encryption only works with software. If the hardware you're running it on is compromised you're SOL. We should also not forget hardware vulnerabilities like specter and meltdown which were hardware bugs that could be exploited by malware to obtain sensitive information.

As long as the keys are on an internet connected device like your smartphone, whatever you encrypt with those keys can potentially be seen by others. We know this from Snowden. Governments have trojans they can install on every connected device and use them to get your keys. The only solution is to have an offline device where you not only store your keys, but where you encrypt and decrypt all messages. QR codes are a convenient way to transport your public key and encrypted messages to and from such an offline device.

E2EE and ZK Proofs are powerful, but for now I fail to see how "revoking" would work, especially with plaintext and images.
If the recipient can "view" the data, they can copy it, whether by storing the view, taking a photo of the screen or even just writing down the content, once it's decrypted it's decrypted, there is no middle ground.
ZK Proofs exist, but they don't allow "viewing" the data, just proving you have the data without revealing it's content, which is not useful for images, for example.

Look at the achelies of anonymous interactions, TOR for instance. Even if they don’t have the data the points of entry and exit required to execute a data transfer are unavoidable, that alone is enough to identify users. Unique identifiers like GUID and MACs are very powerful in aggregate but when sorted by other meta data and time stamps you cant be anon on the internet.

What is needed is session macs and location based session MACs to help disrupt the ease of aggregating data across data pathways. Very complex and it could have risks of lost data due to time sync faults and unexpected connection resets that are all very common issues plaguing web connections.

While I absolutely agree that government surveillance is a huge issue, it is only half the problem, and I really think it's important to spend time explaining the dangers of targeted advertising and manipulation.

This isn't just a matter of trusting large tech companies to protect your data from outside actors, it's a matter of trusting large tech companies to not misuse the data they're holding. Which, again, we shouldn't do because they obviously misuse it. Just look at the Facebook whistleblower we just had.

At the end of the day, this entire discussion is a matter of control. The more information someone has on you, the more control they exert on you. An authoritarian government might proactively discredit you for association with dissidents; information obtained by contact lists and correlated location data. A large food delivery gig company might use advertising to convince you to vote against your interests by appealing to your distaste for big government, your desire for freedom of choice, or your loyalty and ignorance of the nuances depending on your personal political beliefs; information obtained by inferred political stances, transaction records, and topics of interest in news and social media. Or a large social media platform may negligently optimize their suggestions and advertising schemes to spread misinformation, confirmation bias, and hate speech until it leads to significant regressive politics, insurrection, or genocide.

Privacy is important as a means of protecting yourself and your secrets, yes. But it has to expand in scope given our current world. Privacy must also mean keeping information out of the hands of people and organizations who would use it to manipulate you. And that absolutely must include the large, profit-motivated tech companies we've been sharing it with for the past couple decades.

At the end of the day, the major desktop (Windows, macOS) and mobile (Android, iOS) operating systems both perform at base level, a huge amount of telemetry.

There's a good use for telemetry, but the uses Microsoft, Google, and Apple have conjured up are not at all good uses.

Windows 10/11's telemetry settings are even placebo - even for the Basic diagnostics data, they still send about 90% of what they would otherwise.
The selection is just to make the end user think they're doing something, when in reality, they aren't.

I'd argue that this needs to be combatted first, since an operating system being invasive is even more egregious than individual applications.

I'd honestly say that unless Microsoft cleans up their act (good luck! the We <3 Linux stuff is all FUD to hide their eventual EEE plan) and Apple actually DO something with their privacy mindset
that isn't just marketing BS, that Windows/macOS are not at all viable privacy-respecting operating systems.

The Linux kernel, whether it's combined with a GNU or non-GNU userland, is pretty much our only hope to have a privacy-respecting operating system. With Valve pouring effort into Proton after Microsoft pretty
much threatened them in 2013 (not by name), the Steam Deck using SteamOS 3 (or.. as I will call it, Arch with probably the fsync kernel/mesa aco), I think that slowly but surely the "chicken and egg" problem
will be solved once and for all.

While the sentiment of fighting for privacy is nice, i don't think this app is a pragmatic solution to privacy. People use "Big Tech" software because it is widely adopted, and mostly free to use. There are other apps that do similar things that this app is claiming to do, and they fail to compete with big tech. I think there are a couple of reasons why. First, with these apps you can only communicate with other people who have the app. Second, the monetization of privacy apps brings about a big barrier on app adoption rates. You have to make money with this app, so I'm assuming you will have to pay monthly for the apps service. This already puts the app way behind other free services.

I think people generally understand that they are exchanging their data for convenience when using big tech apps. IMO, the only practical way to combat privacy concerns is through legislation. Unfortunately America is so polarized, getting anything done in our legislative bodies is like pulling teeth.

To the "nothing to hide" common argument. I always chuckle when someone says it because it is demonstrably false. EVERYONE has something to hide. They may not know it, but they do. Why? Well, because it's not a matter of whether what you did is actually bad. It only matters if it can be made to look bad. Someone can slap together a few truths about you that give the appearance of a wrong, embarrassing or illegal thing and by the time you get to respond to it, it will have gone viral in 50 states. Another thing that I think people need to realize is it is extremely likely that a substantial number of our elected officials, judges and other key leaders are already compromised. I would be good money that every affair, every shady deal, every corrupt action ever done by any leader in office is known to some 3rd party with a desire to use that information.

Hey Destin, do you know about free software movement?
Free software promotes the idea of free software, "free" as in "freedom".
I heard you mention "open source" close to the end of the video, but a lot of people mistake it as being the same as free software.

Now that you are making a series about privacy, I think it would be smart to include this topic in the series. This is a subject that not that many people know about, but it is very important for everyone running software on their computers and everyone else too.

The idea of free software is to give people the 4 essential freedoms:
0. The freedom to run the program as you wish, for any purpose.
1. The freedom to study how the program works, and change it so it does your computing as you wish. Access to the source code is a precondition for this.
2. The freedom to redistribute copies so you can help your neighbor.
3. The freedom to distribute copies of your modified versions to others. By doing this you can give the whole community a chance to benefit from your changes. Access to the source code is a precondition for this.

Back in the 70s and 80s when I was taking sociology classes, we learned about how credit card and other data gatherers sold, shared, and analyzed every piece of data they could. It was (apocryphally) stated that the KGB was envious of our credit card system because it was easier to track and monitor the people without needing informants or observers -- and we were doing it voluntarily. Again: in the 70s! I also worked in secure areas and was briefly a white-hat (back in the way-back when hackers weren't necessarily construed as evil). Needless to say, I've long accepted that privacy doesn't exist -- even if I like to maintain the illusion of having some control about that. It's long been an open can of digital worms.

Honestly as someone who is studying CS right now, I have come to realize that although it is unethical that big tech does take data ultimately regardless of the company analysts will use the data to improve their algorithms / findings. As long as the operating systems made and controlled by Big Tech companies like Microsoft or Apple continue to be widely-used, the privacy provided by even "secure" apps will be dubious. The OS is where most vulnerabilities are. I think a better way to go would be to develop an OS that is end-to-end encrypted whenever it is communicating with another computer that also uses the same OS. Then any additional app-specific end-to-end encryption should provide extra protection. Of course, the source code would need to be made public so that people could verify the absence of back doors and such.

Really cool, but I foresee a few problems with this.

#1: The product servers and solution is not self-hosted - i.e., "on a server in your basement," so it can still be subpoenaed by the government. The only difference is that now you personally are the one forced to comply.

#2: The product will require a subscription. Banks and institutions can be obligated to share financial information on you, which will show that you have sent payments to this 4Privacy company. They will then have positive identification that you use the service and be able to pursue you for the records contained within.

#3: The product uses a "passwordless" authentication solution. This is a problem, as many jurisdictions DO NOT protect the privacy of digital devices that are not secured with a password. Not a PIN, not a fingerprint, not a face ID - a password. If you use any of the other mentioned authentication solutions, you can be legally forced to provide these and open your data store.

As long as we don't own our devices completely, any app, no matter how focused on privacy it is, is merely a small speed bump for big tech and governments.

If the device and operating system can't be trusted to do what you want, you can't ensure privacy no matter how hard you try.

If you own a modern smart phone or computer, most of what it does internally is completely unknowable to you.

Most of the system libraries, drivers and firmwares which allow the device to work are inaccessible to users and there's little that keeps a company or government agency from adding a backdoor to your device through a patch.

It's easy to add a piece of code which copies the end-to-end encrypted data after it has been transmitted and decrypted, rendering the whole end-to-end encryption process moot.

Dumb advertising is worth a very very small fraction of the value of targeted advertising and definitely not enough to pay the bills of most of your services.

So long as everyone is fine with a monthly subscription for YouTube, being a YouTube creator (They won't pay you anymore they can't profit off of you), facebook, instagram, google search, google maps, wikipedia, twitter, any web based service (your smart phone apps all of them, probably many things i didn't think of and you probably won't either), then its fine...

I would argue a component to it which from my career in data fields, may be even a scarier reality. What our data contains relative to what it shows - is influenced by the observer. Our digital footprint profiling, to group and cluster data points to summarize us and our data movement - in my opinion, depends on the intentions and methods of that aggregation and manipulation. It's a very subjective field to summarize, but I think at least for me personally, that's what concerns me equally, is not just what is captured but what is done with it after. One day, if not already, AI will have digested every bit of digital data on the internet, and how it would summarize it all, and us... That concerns me, but again, not something you can talk about out loud as its out there not here and now.

Crazy side angle is - those people who probably should have their data viewed for national security purposes, are the ones who know/find a way to keep it hidden, legally or not is another discussion - akin to the worst criminals in the world, may or may not already be in jail - the best worst, are likely still uncaught or smartly hidden in plain sight...

Fun side note perhaps, I had a thought a few times to write a letter to AI. To explain myself and my being and my existence and my awareness and my concerns of things we as a species do... So that maybe, just that one extra piece of data digested, might sway the judgement of AI from the myriad of garbage we all in some way contribute to one way or another at some point in our lives. Especially if we consider how AI is so badly portrayed in movies in some cases, just to think if AI watches and comprehends our representation of AI and aligns to it.... we really could be the architects of our own demise! Convenience is a great word you threw in there too btw. I have long felt even in my young age, that our search for convenience and integrating convenience as normality into our lives, runs risks long term... but who knows, maybe all will be fine and ok :)

Privacy is important, but I have some concerns about the app:

1. This app looks to provide secure messaging, password manager, and secure data store (files, documents, etc). That is a lot of major functionality for a single service to provide.
2. The doesn't actually replace other major data leaks (email, social media, search).

This is where I seriously question the vision of having 1 app to do everything. It feels both too big and too small at the same time. Even today, we don't have 1 company that does it all. Therefore, it makes sense to support independent projects that can each do their own thing really well. Perhaps if this app was able to integrate with existing services by "holding their encryption keys", then this would make sense, but looking at the Kickstarter, I don't actually see any evidence of that.

I do not think it's wise to pull all of the eggs into one basket when it comes to infosec. Not only there are other countries who ignore the patriot act alltogether and in which data requests work in different ways. And "have access" is a stretch, considering there are different vectors of attacks, different ways of access and in many cases an AS simply cannot provide the data in questions. And let's not forget that there's a difference between metadata and data analytics, which are collected differently. You can have no accounts in any of the big tech companies and ad agencies will STILL have de-anonymizable data with geolocations, browser info, cross links and more.
And don't forget that between your government and hackers there are also other governments, which would like info on you (may be not you specifically, but someone). More than that, there's a big bulk of data collected via cameras, subway passes, banks and much more, which you can't combat easily.

Another point for the video: there's a big difference between p2p encryption and general encryption, but there's more problems there: encryption is a tricky field to work in and my country, for instance, places harsh laws upon it. You have to be certified and higher risk places like banks or government places, MUST use specific encryption protocols, which have already been called into question. It was noted that the tables created for them are far from random and it probably has a backdoor.

And more than that -- It wasn't "slow". GDPR, 152-FL, USA privacy laws -- they all cropped up BECAUSE of the increased risk of cyber attacks. You worry about your own privacy and your country worries about it's own privacy in turn, so laws are put in place quite fast. But, as you can see from the previous paragraph, not always in the best ways.

It's a great idea to create a universal way to make the internet private, but encryption is a tiny tiny tiny brick in this wall. Third party cookies still have no solution, global data protection laws are at a failing point both internationally and locally and moreover -- because of the way the internet runs these days privacy is a direct conflict of interest for most tech giants, who rely on data. I'd like to see a solution and I love that there are positive steps taken towards privacy in general, but as of right now, I see that privacy is dead. And it's far more probable that the society is going to change, rather than the information flow we live in is going to budge.

Here's the deal: If it looks like you're getting close to achieving what you're trying to do you're going to die. I'm serious. Don't think for one second that government will allow you to block access to knowledge of the private lives and data of the citizens. Knowledge IS power. And, to paraphrase a wise wizard, "....they do not share POWER."

"But why would they want such power over innocent people", goes the argument, usually followed by "I have nothing to hide." Why? Because, as Orwell described, Power is not a means to an end. Power is the end. Power is its own justification. It doesn't have to have a specific reason either good or evil. People seek power because it's power. But be assured: It WILL be used for evil. It always is, eventually. Organizations are composed of people, and people will be people.

I'm really interested to see how this turns out.  I've personally observed that there is a spectrum between "ease of use" and "security".  Things that are very easy to use (fewest number of steps to complete an action) tend to be less secure (easy for unauthorized actors to gain access).  And things that are very secure (difficult for unauthorized actors to gain access) tend to be harder to use (more steps required to complete an action).  There is the expectation that some steps will be added, the question is how many will be added?

The USA's current ideology around data ownership is backwards. They believe that if you give data to a company, it is the company's property. Imagine you are walking around and you step onto Google's lawn: if Google takes pictures of you while you are standing on their property, Google owns those pictures. They never have to tell you they took those pictures, they don't have to get your consent before taking the pictures, it's their property and they get to do whatever they want. The EU's GDPR law is the inverse of this, saying that users have to *explicitly* give consent for a company to *borrow* data from you, because even if the company collects data on their own property, it is still *your* data. The idea that your data is always yours no matter where it sits is the attitude companies and our government need to adopt.

Signal, while being the gold standard for secure messaging still runs on an Android or iOS device, and is still therefore a hostage of the operating system. The OS can read ALL data being put into or taken out of the application. The keyboard can read keystrokes, and the display adapter can read all text and images being output.

If the operating system is corrupt, then nothing running on top of it is secure. End of story.

This does leave me with one big question though: how does preventing companies from using our data affect the economical side of things? Ultimately, the "engine" of the modern internet is financially driven. It costs money to build, maintain, and host the free internet that we experience today. Companies have found a clever way to take user data and turn a profit to offset the aforementioned costs. If companies were prevented from doing this, it would be significantly more difficult to generate the necessary revenue to continue to support the existing infrastructure and they would need to find other ways to be profitable. The most obvious strategy is to just charge users directly to use their services, and I'm not sure I like that option either.

However, I'm not fully convinced that your app, though undoubtedly useful, will be able to fully tackle the gargantuan problem it's supposed to fight. We've long since passed the point where we can no longer trust our operating systems (particularly bad on mobile devices, but desktop just as well). We're running our entire digital existence on hardware that is compromised (whether that's intentional or not is beside the point). Even worse, our mobile phones are not only compromised, they were intentionally designed to be multi-purpose surveillance devices. And if our network connections are tapped at any of the lower layers, we're effectively powerless against any form of meaningful attack.

Speaking of vulnerabilities... would it be naive to belive that exploits like Spectre and Meltdown are *not* intentionally placed backdoors?

All I've heard so far is that privacy is a concern, and you're abso-freak'n-lutely speaking the truth. But... what.. privacy?

If you're being a dimwit and using services that could compromise or share your data, then, .. don't.. put... your...data... there....
If you're bothered that your phone is sending GPS data.. turn GPS off.
If you're bothered that email is being monitored.. learn how to host your own mail server.
If you're bothered about geotaging your texts and images (Which, by the way, some image formats STORE that extra data), then, stop texting, and use a camera that doesn't have GPS built in.

ANYTIME you put YOUR data on someones elses computer, or device, you have LOST control of that data. It doesn't have to be Facebook, or Google, or whomever. If you send a text message to someone, and you are using Peer to Peer encryption where the middleman doesn't see that data, you LOSE control of what is done with that data. There is absolutely NO key that is going to prevent that loss of control unless you just don't post, say or do anything with that information. Even if you take a network cable, plug it into two computers sitting right next to each other, copy ANY kind of data, be it a photo, or text file, or whatever, and that other computer leaves your area, you LOSE CONTROL OF THAT INFORMATION.

Bottom line, don't share information you don't need to share. Don't sign up to services you don't need to be using. Don't sign up for services that "require" your phone number to validate who you are. Don't sign up for services that REQUIRE you to put your REAL information in. Just don't.

I work in IT and the answer is: essentially yes. Our laws don’t protect us well enough from people being able to sell our data. Most people don’t care and use social media and literally give their lives away. It’s more subtle than that, as websites track us through “cookies” and companies keep permanent records of everything we buy and then use that to advertise to us.

Most of it isn’t malicious or insidious, and the reasons are largely banal: folks just want to sell us stuff. However, it’s intrusive and companies like Amazon and possibly Apple have crossed the line with always-on listening. Regrettably, these same devices also expose us to other bad actors.

Edward Snowden revealed that anything we can enable in software, a hacker or government hacker can also enable it clandestinely to spy on us. This should be an issue of tremendous outrage given how we all carry software-enabled cameras and microphones that any hacker can use to spy on us.

IT security is a serious issue that is not well regulated and the protections and boundaries are not desired either by governments or by businesses—but for different reasons. And at the end of the day, the average person is the one who suffers…the story of human history in a nutshell.

I'm not at all convinced that you can keep Google or Apple - who have kernel-mode access to my phone and therefore all of its memory contents - from accessing whatever is on screen at any moment. Also, even disregarding people just taking photos/screenshots of their phone screens, how would you prevent anyone with a rogue 4privacy client from simply storing the decrypted info? Maybe the best you could do is use some hardware DRM or require TPM to sign every executable all the way from bootloader, to kernel, to the 4privacy app itself, which would then require people to relinquish control over their hardware for control over their data. And even then, ARM (or Qualcomm, Apple, Intel, whoever) would still be able to violate your privacy (specially under court orders).

If you allow hardware that you don't control to decrypt anything, then you can just assume that that information is no longer private and never will be again.

Originally, only physical intrusion was protected, but when they were able to fly a helicopter with a telephoto lense and an infra red camera to see over your outside walls and track your movement inside your home... well... that was when the rules change.

Now that your papers and effects are in the custody of third parties as a matter of so much routine that people reasonably expect privacy, that expectation should be included in the 4th amendment.

Glenn Greenwald gave an amazing TED Talk on why privacy matters. I believe one of his most important and best statements was this, about people who say “I have nothing to hide.”-

‘Over the last 16 months, as I've debated this issue around the world, every single time somebody has said to me, "I don't really worry about invasions of privacy because I don't have anything to hide." I always say the same thing to them. I get out a pen, I write down my email address. I say, "Here's my email address. What I want you to do when you get home is email me the passwords to all of your email accounts, not just the nice, respectable work one in your name, but all of them, because I want to be able to just troll through what it is you're doing online, read what I want to read and publish whatever I find interesting. After all, if you're not a bad person, if you're doing nothing wrong, you should have nothing to hide."’

Ok, so with zero knowledge and end-to-end encryption and privacy without compromise.  How do you stop an app like Signal or some variant from becoming the the platform of choice for any terrorist organization, cartel, or pedo ring? Are you going to do a follow-up video on some kind of an individually federated content safety scheme for privacy yet social safety at a billion-user scale? Any privacy scheme is going to smash head first into a social-contract, when the terms-of-service of civilization hit a critical violation, history is littered with precedent (Sedition Acts of 1918, 9/11 -> Patriot Act, Jan 6 2021, or Pandora papers).  I'd love you to interview with someone like Frances Haugen, and/or Daniel Schmachtenberger to explore what might happen when end-to-end privacy tries to scale.

I'm happy to support this effort, and I think it's an important one. However, I hope you address the elephant in the room when it comes to the biggest issue with cloud vs local control: *That privacy is a luxury*. Just like the majority people won't be able to afford an electric car in their lifetime, the majority of people won't have the technical skills or resources to be able to protect their privacy. Not only is it much harder from a technical standpoint to control and manage your own data successfully, but data is what pays for services like Facebook, Google Maps, and even subsidizes products like the Amazon Echo lineup so that they are affordable for the average consumer.

I'm incredibly fortunate to have the technical skills and monetary means to store my data on site, choose local control options, and encrypt my traffic to ensure my own privacy (and make videos about it), but I can tell you that it's not cheap enough, not convenient enough, and not user friendly enough for the vast majority of the population. I don't have a solution, but I'm happy to help where I can.

I trust you Destin. I trust most people want a simple, uncomplicated life. However, those people aren't the ones who are clamoring for this. There is a not-so-small minority of American citizens that would jump at the chance to have the power of the internet and anonymity. Extremism isn't as extreme as it used to be, resulting in harassment, doxxing, and real world confrontations that have resulted in everything from being chased into a bathroom, to a mob that attempted to overturn a legal and accurate election. For decades, we've monitored everything from telegraph to radio transmissions to social media data hoping to catch key words and phrases that demand as much prior warning as possible. The advantages you propose - at first glance - only allow reactive measures IF you can identify the players and the methods they used. These are the very advantages desired by quite a few people who have malicious intent.

I hate the slippery slope argument so I don't promote that thinking here. I only know that the problems I suggest are very clearly already here and in substantial numbers. As a moderate, I hate the idea of unrestrained access. As a veteran, I recognize the need for proactive measures to prevent bad actors. I hope your privacy series goes into more depth with how you avoid replacing one potential abuse of the system with another.

Without wishing to be rude - I'm half-way through the video and I'm still waiting for you to get to the point. You're making a fairly serious argument here, but your argument fundamentally lacks a thesis. I get that the subject matter is not simple and requires explanation, but that explanation ought to follow some kind of central claim that it's building towards. As it stands, I'm required to either already agree with you or else already be immersed in the issues you're discussing in order evaluate the claims you're making. While I do trust your integrity, your narrative is structured in a suspicious way, throwing out superficially disconnected facts as though trying to lead us into a conclusion without having to make it, which comes across as dishonest. Even if it isn't (and I'm pretty sure it isn't), the delivery is still just on the far side of "suspicious" which makes it hard to actually absorb what's being said.

What are you talking about? What are you worried about? What are you trying to accomplish? Open with that, as opposed to this vague "just trust me" angle. Maybe trust ME to be able to absorb a central thesis first before getting a full history lesson.

"It's true that the scientific merit of this experiment is in question" is a heck of an understatement. Something that is always bizarrely left out of popular references to the boiling frog experiment is that the frogs had their brains removed beforehand. The actual noteworthy finding of the experiment was that the frogs would jump out of the water if the water was already boiling even if their brains had been removed.

You are totally right about privacy but missing a bigger point. If everyone's data was locked up and no one could see or use it then there goes the free internet. Like you say the fuel for the engine is data, so what happens when there's no fuel? Are we going to pay for it? Probably not, because not everyone can afford it, so the cost would be high. YouTube for instance is used around the world as a teaching tool to lots of underprivileged kids, should that be stopped? Google provides the world's knowledge at the fingertips of anyone that wants it, should that stop? It allows those under oppressive regimes to get the word out about their situation, do you want to cut them off? Something needs to be done but it's not as simple as turning off the personal data flow from users. If your product worked, the companies would just change their user agreements to request permission to use the data and if it's not given, you don't get to use it without paying, which is actually reasonable. I worry about the sustainability of a project like this. You said it yourself in the video - these big tech companies both don't and aren't allowed to keep your data private. If you're building a product or service specifically designed not to cooperate with government inquiry, you'll be shut down - plain and simple. And if you're building a product that still plans to cooperate with an increasingly totalitarian government (at least with regards to control of data and invasion of privacy) and the only benefit you're offering is better safeguarding against leaks and hacks, you've still got a major uphill fight. Add to that the fact that nothing can or will be done about the vast amounts of each of our data that is ALREADY out there, and this doesn't seem likely to reduce the amount of spam calls/emails, etc. I think if you want to see real change, you need to get those changes made within the laws that being abused, rather than by offering a product or service or that tries to put a bandaid of security theatre overtop a much larger, more complex issue.

I completely agree with the privacy concern, but I have a question which you may already be planning on addressing in a future video: Isn't our information the thing that makes the use of the internet and its services free? I don't mean that as a justification for what big tech is doing, but EVERYTHING is built on the information that is gathered, including the ability for small businesses to reach out to the appropriate audience. I want a fix, but wouldn't ultimate privacy lead to paying to use services that don't collect your information?

Take Facebook for example. Say there is complete privacy and they do not collect any information. How would they, as a business, make money? Advertising through Facebook would become worthless because you couldn't target people most likely to use use your service. You essentially go back to the equivalent billboards and newspaper type of advertising. The same goes for YouTube or Google or Amazon. They all feed each other, giving us the ability to do things we would not be able to do otherwise (and maybe that is what they want us to think).

We ultimately, like you suggested, voluntarily give our information to get what we want, because if we had to pay for the same service with actual money, we wouldn't do it. So I guess my real question is, what is the true cost of our privacy? But with the number of comments you get, the likelihood you see this is slim. I guess I am leaving it to YouTube to get it to you.....

I’m a corporate software developer, and at my company we are always trying to minimize and eliminate personally identifiable information (PII) from our systems whenever we can, keeping just enough to do things like process credit card transactions etc. but ditching other data (like user history beyond what we legally have to keep). It’s corporate policy here and makes tons of sense. For us, PII is a liability and a security risk. Even in the US where they won’t prosecute data breaches, we don’t want the black eye of being THAT company which forced all its users to feel exposed after a hack. So we cut PII out to minimize our vulnerabilities.

But then again, we’re not funded by advertisers. Our users are not the product. And we’re not a social media megacorp with a power-hungry CEO.

Part of the issue is that the internet has never been funded... it ended up relying on advertising (which ironically is what allows this video to be posted and shared for free).   The drive for better advertising is what has been the underlying motivator for "Big tek" to gather more and better information. "You are the product" means you are what sells to pay for the services you now take forgranted.  If that dries up (or degrades), so do the advertising budgets that fund those services.  The internet needs to additionally develop a simple payment model for services because running a data center to host memes is far from free, and that is what people have forgotten.   And in a private future (an excellent goal) that funding needs to come from another source.

And I do have one minor qualm: you toted the increase in wiretapping, etc. as essentially being CAUSATION for increased commercial collection of data, but I think it's actually just really strong CORRELATION, and the real cause is that companies are exponentially realizing how profitable it can be, as they see other companies profit from it and learn to do it. It's a similar trend to how subscription & leasing revenue models have exploded in the past decade or so.

So, the PROFITABILITY of collecting user data (and the ever-increasing awareness of its profitability) is the real cause, IMO.

Government surveillance/wiretapping just correlates strongly because it is dependent on most of the same technological advancements as commercial user data collection.

*Edit*: Also, the VALUE of user data is equally in aggregation and in individual profiling, so as data becomes either more aggregated or more user-specific, it becomes equally more profitable, as its commercial value scales in-tow.

Interesting app, Destin. The greatest technical challenge is to create privately owned and managed Certificate Authorities by “subscriber”. If the user community all subscribe to a public CA, then there is little chance of the master key not being compromised and used to decrypt content. The algorithm alone to constantly rotate keys to eliminate State actors from deciphering the keys is a massive undertaking.

One option is to consider a different protocol that includes encryption and Zero Trust natively, yet still operates over public services. Host Identity Protocol comes to mind. It has many of the benefits you describe (already an IETF standard with multiple RFCs behind it) but you still have to solve the CA. And that does not include encryption-at-rest, though many OS already do.

I'm not fully convinced. Admittedly there are horrible effects that result from a lack of privacy. A few I can think of are:
1) data can be used by other countries to stir up social unrest using targeted social media campaigns
2) It can detur good journalists from criticizing the government under fear they can't remain anonymous
3) etc

But the sense of paranoia I get from people who are obsessed with privacy doesn't seem proportional to these risks. In my experience, most people erroneously extrapolate privacy rights from physical to digital information. There are different types of data transfer, and some are worse than others. For example, just looking at the person crossing the street is a form of data transfer (since you can approximate his weight, size, bla bla) yet it's largely benign. Lastly, there are other strongly negative risks associated with complete data privacy: scientific research, anti-terrorism efforts, etc).

If you disagree with me please let me know your thoughts and explain (nicely) why you think privacy should be protected apriori.

Do you know how the US Intelligence community actually solved that terrorist attack? It scanned domestic and international phone calls for the 12 months preceding and following that date, scanning for keywords. Then, they set about conducting human surveillance. So what’s the interesting point? That they had they technical means to perform the analysis on analog phone calls, OR that they had the DATA on which to perform it?
This single incident should be proof enough to anyone that the US Govt runs unchecked in their breach of the 4th Amendment by shrouding themselves with a cause of “National Security”. FISA warrant abuse is rampant, and no Congressional Oversight will ever thwart our Intel community from their tactics.

You say, “I have nothing to hide” so you don’t care. It is precisely when you are the least vulnerable that you must become the most vigilant because circumstances change and tomorrow may be “your day”.

You have to be able to solve the root problem that is driving the sharing of information with tech companies: free services. We all love free services, like free email, YouTube, Facebook, Twitter, etc. Those services are free to us because we are the product being sold. We "pay" for these services with our information. This is cool, but there's a flaw in your engine analogy. The privacy is important, but it doesn't actually replace the current engine of the internet with another thing that can continue to power the internet.

As well as being useful for various kinds of nosy people, personal data is used to choose ads to show you, which pays for the stuff you use without inserting cash. There have to be a lot more ads to have the same effect if they aren't targeted, and that wrecks the experience. When you take away the private information, you remove the ability of the company that's giving you no-cash email / video / social media to get its other steam of money from you, and eventually when enough people do this, the companies go out of business. The privacy starves the private-data-fueled engine of oxygen, it doesn't replace that engine.

I'm definitely not saying that the current internet payment plan is a good thing, or that our data should be freely available for governments to receive, and in fact the surveillance is much worse than is depicted here. But if we want everybody to be protected, we need a different route than this, because not all people will take these steps, and if they did it wouldn't be sustainable for the free-to-use internet that you're used to.

I don't know what the big solution is. And having more people do real end-to-end encryption might be the only way to force the societal conversation, since governments won't willing give up their easy source of mass surveillance.
